articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — While much of the nation’s attention was focused on the gun massacres in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, last weekend, Chicago was convulsed by its own burst of violence — the worst weekend the city has seen so far in 2019.

articles.snippet: Attacks like that in El Paso are not an end in themselves. They are a call to arms, toward something much more frightening.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like a number of recent mass shootings, the one in El Paso on Saturday came with a manifesto. While authorities are still working to verify that this document explicitly was indeed written by the attacker, the evidence seems clear: It was posted to 8Chan minutes before the attack, by someone with the same name.

articles.snippet: The Walmart where the shooting happened, just miles from the United States’ border with Mexico, reflected bicultural life in El Paso.
articles.lead_paragraph: In many ways, it was a Walmart like all the others: a place to buy groceries, to pick up new school supplies and sometimes even to splurge on cosmetics. But then an ordinary Saturday morning for shoppers in El Paso was abruptly upended when a gunman opened fire in the store.
articles.abstract: The Walmart where the shooting happened, just miles from the United States’ border with Mexico, reflected bicultural life in El Paso.

articles.snippet: Mass shootings like the one in El Paso should be condemned by America’s leaders as terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: If one of the perpetrators of this weekend’s two mass shootings had adhered to the ideology of radical Islam, the resources of the American government and its international allies would mobilize without delay.

articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s usual methods of deflection sputtered as he faced new criticism and scrutiny for the plain echoes of his own rhetoric in the El Paso gunman’s anti-immigrant manifesto.
articles.lead_paragraph: The politics of American gun violence follow a predictable pattern in most cases: outraged calls for action from the left, somber gestures of sympathy from the right, a subdued presidential statement delivered from a prepared text — and then, in a matter of days or even hours, a national turning of the page to other matters.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s usual methods of deflection sputtered as he faced new criticism and scrutiny for the plain echoes of his own rhetoric in the El Paso gunman’s anti-immigrant manifesto.

articles.snippet: There may be as many motivations as there are killers. But over the decades, scientists have seen some patterns emerge.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, President Trump made his first televised statement about the mass murders committed over the weekend in El Paso, Tex., and Dayton, Ohio. He called for action to “stop mass killings before they start,” citing what he said were a number contributing factors: the contagious nature of mass murder; the glorification of violence in video games; and the need to act on “red flags” to identify and potentially confine the “mentally ill monsters” that he said commit the crimes.
articles.abstract: There may be as many motivations as there are killers. But over the decades, scientists have seen some patterns emerge.

headline.main: What Experts Know About People Who Commit Mass Shootings

articles.snippet: The authorities are considering charging the suspect with federal hate crimes, as well as federal gun charges that would carry the death penalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators in El Paso said they were treating the massacre at a Walmart that killed 20 and wounded another 27 on Saturday morning as an act of domestic terrorism, and prosecutors said they were considering federal hate crime charges. They were also considering federal gun charges that would carry the death penalty.
articles.abstract: The authorities are considering charging the suspect with federal hate crimes, as well as federal gun charges that would carry the death penalty.

headline.main: El Paso Shooting: Massacre That Killed 20 Being Investigated as Domestic Terrorism

articles.snippet: In a country that has become nearly numb to men with guns opening fire in schools, at concerts and in churches, shooting in Texas and Ohio left the public shaken.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — On Sunday, Americans woke up to news of a shooting rampage in an entertainment district in Dayton, Ohio, where a man wearing body armor shot and killed nine people, including his own sister. Hours earlier, a 21-year-old with a rifle entered a Walmart in El Paso and killed 20 people.
articles.abstract: In a country that has become nearly numb to men with guns opening fire in schools, at concerts and in churches, shooting in Texas and Ohio left the public shaken.

headline.main: Back-to-Back Outbreaks of Gun Violence in El Paso and Dayton Stun Country
headline.print_headline: One Shooting Massacre Follows Another, Shaking a Bewildered Nation to Its Core

byline.original: By Campbell Robertson, Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith

articles.snippet: The gun lobby has structural advantages and a Senate aligned with its stance. But activists have increased financing and grass-roots energy as they pursue their cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The political momentum in the gun control debate has shifted in the year leading up to this weekend’s mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, with gun control advocates taking a more empowered stance and the National Rifle Association consumed by internal power struggles.
articles.abstract: The gun lobby has structural advantages and a Senate aligned with its stance. But activists have increased financing and grass-roots energy as they pursue their cause.

articles.snippet: This is what happens when our nation’s leader normalizes hate.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Like most Americans, I watched, devastated, as the news began to unfold Saturday morning. Another deadly mass shooting. This time in El Paso, and soon after Dayton, Ohio. In El Paso, 22 lives were taken; dozens more families and communities have been left to suffer in its wake.
articles.abstract: This is what happens when our nation’s leader normalizes hate.

articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — “White nationalist terrorism.” “America’s new civil war.” “‘Domestic terrorists’ devastate the U.S.” After two mass shootings rocked the United States last weekend, headlines from Sydney to Paris depicted the bloodshed as America battling itself.

articles.snippet: Like the mobs that killed Americans of Mexican descent across the West in the early 20th century, the El Paso shooting suspect believed that Texas was better off as a territory run by, and for, white people.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the cities and towns of California, Colorado, Arizona and other Western states, there are countless highways of memory leading back to El Paso. That Texas border town on the Rio Grande, site of a horrific mass shooting on Saturday, is the Ellis Island of the American Southwest.
articles.abstract: Like the mobs that killed Americans of Mexican descent across the West in the early 20th century, the El Paso shooting suspect believed that Texas was better off as a territory run by, and for, white people.

articles.snippet: How much responsibility does President Trump bear for violence motivated by racism? The columnists discuss gun control, the recent shootings in El Paso, Tex. and Dayton, Ohio and their connections to Trump’s dehumanizing statements about immigrant...
articles.lead_paragraph: How much responsibility does President Trump bear for violence motivated by racism? The columnists discuss gun control, the recent shootings in El Paso, Tex. and Dayton, Ohio and their connections to Trump’s dehumanizing statements about immigrants. Then, several 2020 Democrats took shots at Barack Obama’s legacy during last week’s presidential debates. Were they just trying to undermine Joe Biden’s appeal, or does the breakup with the most recent Democratic president signify something deeper?
articles.abstract: How much responsibility does President Trump bear for violence motivated by racism? The columnists discuss gun control, the recent shootings in El Paso, Tex. and Dayton, Ohio and their connections to Trump’s dehumanizing statements about immigrants. Then, several 2020 Democrats took shots at Barack Obama’s legacy during last week’s presidential debates. Were they just trying to undermine Joe Biden’s appeal, or does the breakup with the most recent Democratic president signify something deeper?

articles.snippet: Federal authorities say they want to employ the same approach used in battling global extremism. But there are political and civil rights concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Law enforcement officials have sounded the alarm for months: Homegrown terrorism, including by white supremacists, is now as big a threat as terrorism from abroad. But the mass shooting in El Paso last weekend, the largest domestic terrorist attack against Hispanics in modern history, has made it glaringly clear how poorly prepared the country is to fight it.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities say they want to employ the same approach used in battling global extremism. But there are political and civil rights concerns.

articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — After 22 people were shot to death at a Walmart in El Paso over the weekend, a Florida retiree found herself imagining how her grandchildren could be killed. A daughter of Ecuadorean immigrants cried alone in her car. A Texas lawyer bought a gun to defend his family.
articles.abstract: The shooting attack in El Paso has left many Latinos deeply shaken, raising questions about their place in American society.

articles.snippet: The bullets ripped through one woman, shredding her intestines and leaving holes the size of a man’s fist in her side. But surgeons had to work fast, clearing the operating room to make way for other victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: The woman, grievously wounded in the mass shooting at a Walmart, lay on an operating table at the University Medical Center of El Paso as the chief of surgery, Dr. Alan Tyroch, turned her to clean the exit wounds. He knew what to expect, but it was still a horrific sight. She had two gaping holes the size of a man’s fist in her side and a third the size of a silver dollar where bullets had burst from her body.
articles.abstract: The bullets ripped through one woman, shredding her intestines and leaving holes the size of a man’s fist in her side. But surgeons had to work fast, clearing the operating room to make way for other victims.

headline.print_headline: President Plans Visits to Places Where Grief Mixes With Anger at Him

byline.original: By Michael Crowley, Rick Rojas and Campbell Robertson

articles.snippet: State laws that let judges take guns away from troubled owners have been used thousands of times, though they work only when people report threatening behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, a man who worked at a car dealership in San Diego told his co-workers that he would shoot up the place if he were fired, and he praised the man who had carried out the Las Vegas massacre.
articles.abstract: State laws that let judges take guns away from troubled owners have been used thousands of times, though they work only when people report threatening behavior.

headline.main: Red Flag Laws Can Save Lives. Shootings in El Paso and Dayton May Expand Them.
headline.print_headline: ‘Red Flag’ Laws Aren’t Airtight, but Officials Say They’ve Saved Lives

articles.snippet: The president became frustrated over his news coverage and his angry reaction led to White House-distributed media that focused on him, not people affected by the shootings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time President Trump arrived in El Paso on Wednesday, on the second leg of a trip to meet with people affected by mass shootings in two cities, he was frustrated that his attacks on his political adversaries had resulted in more coverage than the cheery reception he received at a hospital in Dayton, Ohio, the first stop on his trip. So he screamed at his aides to begin producing proof that in El Paso people were happy to see him.
articles.abstract: The president became frustrated over his news coverage and his angry reaction led to White House-distributed media that focused on him, not people affected by the shootings.

headline.main: Trump’s Trip to Dayton and El Paso: The Back Story
headline.print_headline: Thumbs Up and All Smiles, the President Strains to Send a Message

byline.original: By Katie Rogers, Maggie Haberman and Rick Rojas

articles.snippet: We can’t misuse the charge in an effort to suppress protected speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the wake of the El Paso shootings, Representative Joaquin Castro of Texas created a stir with a tweet on his official account listing the names and employers of 44 residents of the San Antonio area who had contributed up to the legal limit to the Trump campaign. The information was a matter of public record but not widely known.
articles.abstract: We can’t misuse the charge in an effort to suppress protected speech.

headline.main: Joaquin Castro’s Tweet Was Not Doxxing
headline.print_headline: A Tweet, Not Online  Harassment

articles.snippet: In the wake of the mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday emphasized the urgent need to confront gun violence in America.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — One by one, Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday emphasized the urgent need to confront gun violence in America, speaking largely in harmony on an issue that has been thrust to the forefront after last weekend’s mass shootings in El Paso and in Dayton, Ohio.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday emphasized the urgent need to confront gun violence in America.

headline.main: Democrats in Iowa Offer Plans to Combat Gun Violence
headline.print_headline: In Combating Gun Violence, Democrats Present a United Front

articles.snippet: Universal Pictures said it pulled the movie, which is about people being hunted for sport, after two mass shootings left 31 dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Universal Pictures on Saturday canceled plans to release “The Hunt” — a thriller about a group of “globalist elites” killing people for sport — after two recent mass shootings that left a total of 31 people dead in El Paso and in Dayton, Ohio.
articles.abstract: Universal Pictures said it pulled the movie, which is about people being hunted for sport, after two mass shootings left 31 dead.

headline.main: Movie Studio Cancels Release of ‘The Hunt’: ‘Now Is Not the Right Time’
headline.print_headline: Movie Studio Cancels Release of ‘The Hunt’ in Response to Shootings

articles.snippet: After waiving his Miranda rights, the suspect said he had used an AK-47-style rifle to carry out the killings, according to an affidavit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The suspect in the El Paso shooting stepped out of a vehicle with his hands up and declared “I’m the shooter” when he was arrested minutes after the massacre at a Walmart that killed 22 people, the police said in an affidavit filed Friday.
articles.abstract: After waiving his Miranda rights, the suspect said he had used an AK-47-style rifle to carry out the killings, according to an affidavit.

headline.main: ‘I’m the Shooter’: El Paso Suspect Confessed to Targeting Mexicans, Police Say
headline.print_headline: Gunman Said He Was Aiming For Mexicans

articles.snippet: The presidential candidate is back in the spotlight after a tragedy in a city that is core to his personal and political identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — As Beto O’Rourke waded through a crowd that had gathered Thursday night to honor victims of the mass shooting in El Paso, the struggling presidential candidate was welcomed as a hometown hero.
articles.abstract: The presidential candidate is back in the spotlight after a tragedy in a city that is core to his personal and political identity.

headline.main: After El Paso Shooting, Will Voters Revisit Beto O’Rourke?
headline.print_headline: In a City’s Grief, O’Rourke Finds A Second Wind

articles.snippet: Until we understand what really drives extremists, we will not be able to stop them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Domestic right-wing terrorists, like the man accused of the shooting last weekend in El Paso, are not so different from their radical Islamist counterparts across the globe — and not only in their tactics for spreading terror or in their internet-based recruiting. Indeed, it is impossible to understand America’s resurgence of reactionary extremism without understanding it as a fundamentally religious phenomenon.
articles.abstract: Until we understand what really drives extremists, we will not be able to stop them.

headline.main: The Religious Hunger of the Radical Right
headline.print_headline: Religious Hunger on the Far Right

articles.snippet: After the shooting in El Paso, Mr. O’Rourke decided to abandon his focus on early primary states and more directly confront the president over immigration and gun control.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beto O’Rourke introduced himself to the country as a changed candidate on Thursday, with his presidential campaign recast as a moral crusade against President Trump in the aftermath of a mass shooting in El Paso, his hometown.
articles.abstract: After the shooting in El Paso, Mr. O’Rourke decided to abandon his focus on early primary states and more directly confront the president over immigration and gun control.

headline.main: Beto O’Rourke’s New Approach to 2020: ‘Taking the Fight to Donald Trump’

articles.snippet: Antonio Basco said he would welcome anyone at his wife’s funeral service this week. People who never knew her are buying flowers, and planning to attend.
articles.lead_paragraph: When his wife was killed in the El Paso shooting this month, Antonio Basco lost not only his partner of 22 years, but also his only relative.
articles.abstract: Antonio Basco said he would welcome anyone at his wife’s funeral service this week. People who never knew her are buying flowers, and planning to attend.

headline.main: His Only Relative Was Killed in the El Paso Massacre. He Has Invited the City to Her Funeral.
headline.print_headline: At a Funeral for an El Paso Victim, All Are Welcome

articles.snippet: He invited everyone in El Paso to his wife’s funeral. But he tends to her garden, alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — Just about every morning for the past two weeks, Antonio Basco has risen before dawn to buy as many floral bouquets as he can fit in his car and carried them to a makeshift memorial for the victims of the mass shooting in El Paso.
articles.abstract: He invited everyone in El Paso to his wife’s funeral. But he tends to her garden, alone.

headline.main: In El Paso, Hundreds Show Up to Mourn a Woman They Didn’t Know
headline.print_headline: Hundreds of Strangers Supporting a Widower, Congregate in El Paso

articles.snippet: The renovated store will include a memorial to the victims and should be ready by the holidays, Walmart said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Walmart in El Paso where a gunman targeted Mexicans in a shooting rampage this month is expected to reopen later this year — and when it does, the store won’t be recognizable to customers and employees, the company said on Thursday.
articles.abstract: The renovated store will include a memorial to the victims and should be ready by the holidays, Walmart said.

headline.main: Walmart to Overhaul and Reopen El Paso Store Where 22 People Were Killed

articles.snippet: A letter sent out by Gov. Greg Abbott before the El Paso shooting asking donors to “defend Texas” from illegal immigration has angered Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Typically, a campaign plea from a Texas governor calling for fellow Republicans to “defend Texas” from illegal immigration and “take matters into our own hands” would be met with a collective yawn. Such appeals have been commonplace in Republican-controlled Texas, where taking a hard line on immigration is a given.
articles.abstract: A letter sent out by Gov. Greg Abbott before the El Paso shooting asking donors to “defend Texas” from illegal immigration has angered Democrats.

headline.main: In Aftermath of El Paso Attack, a Reckoning on Texas’s Divisive Political Rhetoric
headline.print_headline: Texas Democrats Urge G.O.P. to ‘Eradicate’ Incendiary Rhetoric

byline.original: By Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery

articles.snippet: Mario De Alba was wounded in the massacre at an El Paso Walmart this month. He remains hospitalized, and his relatives have uprooted their lives in Mexico to be with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — They stand beside him, smoothing his black hair, holding his hands, massaging his feet and making him laugh. Mario De Alba’s loved ones have kept this bedside vigil inside an El Paso hospital room, 28 days and counting, for the washer-and-dryer repairman now called the Hero of Chihuahua.
articles.abstract: Mario De Alba was wounded in the massacre at an El Paso Walmart this month. He remains hospitalized, and his relatives have uprooted their lives in Mexico to be with him.

headline.main: ‘My World Has Now Stopped’: How One Family Is Recovering From a Mass Shooting
headline.print_headline: Life Stalled, a Family Strives to Recover From the El Paso Shooting

articles.snippet: After shootings in Dayton and El Paso last month, the issue was already expected to top the agenda when lawmakers return from their recess next week. Now the pressure has intensified.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The deadly shooting spree in West Texas this weekend — the latest in an especially gruesome summer of massacres — has intensified pressure on congressional Republicans to take up gun safety legislation, giving fresh urgency to a debate that was already expected to be at the top of lawmakers’ agenda when they return to the Capitol next week.
articles.abstract: After shootings in Dayton and El Paso last month, the issue was already expected to top the agenda when lawmakers return from their recess next week. Now the pressure has intensified.

headline.main: Texas Shooting Brings New Urgency to Gun Debate in Congress
headline.print_headline: Texas Shooting Adds Urgency In Washington

articles.snippet: Doug McMillon, Walmart’s chief executive, said the company would stop selling certain types of guns and ammunition. This should be an example for corporate America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Midday Tuesday, Doug McMillon, Walmart’s chief executive, sent me a surprise email. He shared a series of policies the company was about to make public about combating gun violence since the mass shooting that killed 22 people at one of his El Paso stores last month.
articles.abstract: Doug McMillon, Walmart’s chief executive, said the company would stop selling certain types of guns and ammunition. This should be an example for corporate America.

headline.main: Walmart’s C.E.O. Steps Into the Gun Debate. Other C.E.O.s Should Follow.
headline.print_headline: Big Business Gets Lesson From Chief Of Walmart

articles.snippet: President Trump said officers and civilians who faced the mass shootings responded with “the best of American courage, character and strength.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It took just 20 seconds for police officers in Dayton, Ohio, to begin firing at a gunman one morning last month, taking him down after he  killed nine people and wounded 27 others in the city’s entertainment district.
articles.abstract: President Trump said officers and civilians who faced the mass shootings responded with “the best of American courage, character and strength.”

headline.main: Trump Honors Police Officers and Civilians in El Paso and Dayton Shootings
headline.print_headline: Trump Honors Police and Civilians in El Paso and Dayton Shootings

articles.snippet: Investors and customers can make corporate America do more than the law requires on gun violence and global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: After recent mass shootings, including one in a Walmart in El Paso, Walmart’s chief executive, Doug McMillon, announced that his company would stop selling ammunition for military-style assault rifles, remove handguns from stores in Alaska — the only Walmarts still carrying them — and ask armed people in open-carry states to stay out of its stores.
articles.abstract: Investors and customers can make corporate America do more than the law requires on gun violence and global warming.

headline.main: Making Companies Act When Government Won’t
headline.print_headline: Forcing Companies to Be Good Citizens

articles.abstract: Luis Calvillo survived the mass shooting at an El Paso Walmart on Aug. 3. Then came the hard part — the long, painful odyssey of recovery.
articles.snippet: Luis Calvillo survived the mass shooting at an El Paso Walmart on Aug. 3. Then came the hard part — the long, painful odyssey of recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — Luis Calvillo has an angel on his shoulder.

headline.main: 88 Days of Recovery: How a Girls’ Soccer Team Healed a Broken Coach
headline.print_headline: 88 Days of Recovery

articles.abstract: Manny Fernandez, our Houston Bureau Chief, and Tamir Kalifa, a photographer, discuss spending nearly three months with Luis Calvillo, who was seriously wounded at the Walmart shooting in El Paso, and his family.
articles.snippet: Manny Fernandez, our Houston Bureau Chief, and Tamir Kalifa, a photographer, discuss spending nearly three months with Luis Calvillo, who was seriously wounded at the Walmart shooting in El Paso, and his family.
articles.lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline.main: Capturing a Shooting Survivor’s Long Recovery, With Humanity
headline.print_headline: A Shooting Survivor’s Long Recovery

keywords.value: University Medical Center of El Paso
